info.game_comments: Battle of the Decades: The 1980s game 3.

double_jeopardy_round: STARTS & ENDS WITH THE SAME VOWEL

(1, 1).clue: These are the regions within about 1,600 miles north & south of the equator

(2, 1).clue: Its Commercial Appeal:"Whither Beale Street? Take It to the River"

(3, 1).clue: In art Saint Agnes is often depicted with this animal, "agnus" in Latin

(4, 1).clue: A source, perhaps of knowledge or wisdom

(5, 1).clue: He won an Emmy for portraying Liberace in "Behind the Candelabra"

(6, 1).clue: I like that "It was raining" is the first line of a story about "Life" in this city where Henry mainly lived from 1876 on

(1, 2).clue: The emmer type of this was one of the first cultivated crops over 10,000 years ago

(2, 2).clue: Its World-Herald:"Huskers Headed to Gator Bowl for Rematch with Georgia"

(3, 2).clue: Embittered by Rome, this translator of the Vulgate took some virgins & went to the Holy Land for good

(4, 2).clue: Moliere's "Tartuffe" is this type of comedy

(5, 2).clue: This star of "Glee" made her Broadway debut at age 8 playing Cosette in "Les Miz"

(6, 2).clue: I like the symbolism in this novel, such as the shattering of the title object

(1, 3).clue: North Dakota is a leading producer of this low-grade brown coal

(2, 3).clue: Its Dispatch:"Beagle Helps Ohio Zoos Tell If Polar Bear Pregnant"

(3, 3).clue: A street festival in NYC's Little Italy is named this, after the saint also called Januarius

(4, 3).clue: It can be a woman's dress or an old-fashioned coat for men

(5, 3).clue: In the '90s his "you got the right one baby" Diet Pepsi commercials earned him a new generation of fans--uh huh!

(6, 3).clue: I like the novel "What" this little girl "Knew", & the 2013 movie based on it too

(1, 4).clue: This period, the "age of fishes", was named for a fossil-rich part of southwest England

(2, 4).clue: Its Register:"Branstad, Grassley Take Different Tacks on Tea Party"

(3, 4).clue: Gregory of this is named for the French city where he lived, not for showing people around

(5, 4).clue: She played the movie star on "Gilligan's Island"

(6, 4).clue: Henry dealt with radical feminism in this novel whose title tells you it's set in Massachusetts

(1, 5).clue: This puny type of tide has the smallest difference between high & low

(2, 5).clue: Its Star:"Ball State Freshman Sinks Half-Court Shot to Win Free Tuition"

(3, 5).clue: He founded an order & monastery at Monte Cassino, where he wrote his "Holy Rules"

(4, 5).clue: It's an antonym of tame for animals

(5, 5).clue: He won a 1965 Oscar for his dual role as a gunfighter & his evil, noseless twin brother in "Cat Ballou"

(6, 5).clue: I'd have liked to meet this "lady" that an 1881 novel is "the portrait" of

(1, 1).clue: We're not neutral about "Un ballo in maschera", about the assassination of a king of this Scandinavian country

(2, 1).clue: This Russian president helped put down the 1991 coup that briefly imprisoned Mikhail Gorbachev

(3, 1).clue: "Ocular" term for something unpleasant to see

(4, 1).clue: The Sterns of New Jersey won a 1980s custody battle with the surrogate mother of Melissa, better known as "Baby" this

(5, 1).clue: The idea for this 1954 Elia Kazan film came from a series of newspaper articles about corruption on the docks

(6, 1).clue: Thunder Bay in Ontario, an arm of this Great Lake

(1, 2).clue: Smitten by Mathilde Wesendonck, Wagner composed this lovey-dovey 1865 opera

(2, 2).clue: In 1989 the Soviets left this country where they'd suffered 15,000 dead during a 10-year quagmire

(3, 2).clue: This pea family crop is like steak to horses

(4, 2).clue: The 1984 U.S. law mandating treatment of seriously ill newborns is known by this generic name

(5, 2).clue: William Holden's acceptance speech upon winning the Oscar for playing a P.O.W. in this film was a terse "Thank you"

(6, 2).clue: Mount Katahdin in this New England state

(1, 3).clue: In an 1893 opera, Lescaut seems to have no first name, but this sister of his does

(2, 3).clue: The name of this Soviet foreign minister during WWII became synonymous with a bottle bomb

(3, 3).clue: This palindromic male given name comes from a Germanic word meaning "rich"

(4, 3).clue: They're called whitecoats, & people got mad at Canada in the '80s for hunting them

(5, 3).clue: Steve McQueen's first starring role was in this film about a gelatinous mass from outer space

(6, 3).clue: The Museum of Porcelain on Grande Rue in this city just outside Paris, famous for making the stuff

(1, 4).clue: One of the many composers to write a "Faust" opera, he was buddies with Bizet

(2, 4).clue: This official Soviet news agency was the main news source for all newspapers & radio & TV stations

(3, 4).clue: This term for ignorant folks sounds like but is the opposite of illuminati

(4, 4).clue: She survived for 21 days in 1984 with a transplanted baboon heart

(5, 4).clue: This actress was a frequent presence in the films of John Ford

(6, 4).clue: The banks of this African river that flows between Zimbabwe & Zambia on its way to the Indian Ocean

(1, 5).clue: Like its heroine, "The Italian Girl in Algiers" did some traveling as this composer's first opera staged in France & Germany

(2, 5).clue: The USSR mounted a 1958 exhibit not of Norman Rockwell but of this left-wing artist with Rockwell as his first name

(3, 5).clue: From the Italian, it's heartburn or anxiety

(4, 5).clue: In 1981 Elizabeth Carr became the USA's first of these babies, with less fanfare than the one across the pond

(5, 5).clue: Leopoldine Konstantin tells Claude Rains, "We are protected by the enormity of your stupidity" in this Hitchcock film

(6, 5).clue: This country to gaze up at the cuneiform Behistun Inscription 300 feet up a sheer limestone cliff

(0, 0).clue: Of the element symbols that don't match the element's English name, this element's symbol is alphabetically 1st
